Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research BCC-SBE: Using Archival Resources to Conduct Data-Intensive Internet Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Description: The BCC-SBE Collaborative Research Project, "Using Archival Resources to Conduct Data-Intensive Internet Research," has three goals: (1) to build a community of scholars focused on tackling next-generation questions of Internet research through the use of archival digital data; (2) to create sample databases and develop a prototype research tool, HistoryTracker, using data from the Internet Archive, a library of Web pages from the World Wide Web; and (3) to maintain an active community of scholars using the cutting-edge community platform HUBzero. Co-PIs Weber, Lazer and Carpenter will lead a community building initiative to coalesce scholars around these three goals. In the long-run, this work will support ongoing interactions among community participants, including the collection of feedback, sharing research, and dissemination of databases collected through the course of this research and beyond. Convenient, efficient access to archival Internet data has the potential to open up countless new avenues of social science research. In addition, evidence from this research project will inform the creation and dissemination of general guidelines for conducting theoretically and methodologically rigorous longitudinal research using archival Web data.

Broader Significance/Nontechnical: The Internet Archive is the single largest repository of archive Web data in existence, yet there is a significant lack of research-ready databases and tools available to the scholarly community. Funding of the BCC-SBE Collaborative Research Project, "Using Archival Resources to Conduct Data-Intensive Internet Research," will inform the creation and dissemination of general guidelines for conducting theoretically and methodologically rigorous longitudinal research using archival Web data. Co-PIs Weber, Lazer and Carpenter will work to bring together a community of scholars focused on research utilizing archival digital data. Subsequently, the principal investigators will lead the development of initial tools and sample databases for conducting ongoing research examining numerous issues pertaining to the development of the World Wide Web, and the behavior of individuals and organizations on the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using Archival Resources to Conduct Data-Intensive Internet Research was a four-year, NSF-funded grant awarded to Rutgers University and the Internet Archive. The program had three primary outcomes: the development research data sets extracted from Internet Archive web data; a platform for community engagement and tool development to support research utilizing archived web data; and a conference to build community and foster collaboration.

With regards to intellectual merit, this research has enabled the launching of a series of new research projects based on archived Internet data, and the growth of an intellectual community using archived Internet data to address a host of social science questions. With regards to the broader impact of this project, this research and the collaborative efforts of this project has supported the doctoral education of more than 60 students, and has supported the growth a community with impacts in the social sciences, library studies, computer science and beyond.

Datasets

The team at Rutgers University worked hand-in-hand with the Internet Archive and Northeastern University to extract and test datasets from web archive collections held by the Internet Archive. These datasets documented three research areas: politics, social movements and disaster resilience. Datasets include the 20th Century Collection, Hurricane Katrina, Senate & House.gov, Occupy Wall Street, Superstorm Sandy, and US Media collections. The datasets and research contribute to the integration of large-scale data analysis techniques into social sciences graduate education.

 

Education

The project has provided numerous opportunities for education and development in the areas of engineering and technology. Working with PhD students from Social Sciences and Computer Science, the project has provided opportunities to teach about social science research implications from large-scale data. New techniques have been developed to extracted data from archived formats to research ready formats, which have required significant collaboration and integration of knowledge from the social sciences and computer science. In the later years of the project, the Archives Unleashed datathons provided further opportunities to support graduate student education through training and hands-on experience.

 

Conference

The project’s main conference, Working with Internet Archives for REsearch (WIRE), took place in June 2014 at the Institute for Quantitative Social Science Research at Harvard University in Cambridge, MA. The workshop was a two-day event, featuring discussions focused on historical research potential, technical challenges, and social science research. More than 30 researchers came together for the workshop, and have continued to engage in discussion since the workshop. Ongoing discussions have taken place via the ArchiveHub website, and via a listserv setup to promote ongoing discussion.

 

Platform and tools for community interaction 

Subsequent to the workshop, the ArchiveHUB website (http://archivehub.rutgers.edu) served as the project's central portal, gathering collective input, sharing updates, and ultimately publishing databases collected through the course of this research. A primary goal of ArchiveHub was to bring together a community of social science researchers focused on tackling questions of Internet research using datasets extracted by this grant. In addition to ArchiveHub, the Archives Unleashed workshop series provided an expanded forum for engagement (archivesunleashed.com) and has further enhanced the robustness of the community.

 

HistoryTracker is an open-source tool that allows for the extraction of social network data from data held at the Internet Archive and made available via the ArchiveHub website. HistoryTracker gives researchers the ability to analyse how the Internet changes over time. Mastering research with large-scale data, both in terms of building usable sets of Web pages and visualizing the networks of topics contained on the Web historically, will be one of the major challenges for scholars in the years to come as the Web continues to grow as a key source of social information. Most efforts to understand the structure and impact of the Web have so far been limited to cross-sectional snapshots. With the development of HistoryTracker, researchers now have a format that can be easily accessed by social science researchers using a wide range of analysis packages.

 

In addition to the above successes, three notable collaborations have emerged out of the WIRE workshop success. First, the Rutgers University team partnered with the Internet Archive, and with researchers at Stanford University and the University of North Texas, to launch a project developing new APIs that will create better access to archived Internet data (funding was obtained from the Institute of Museum and Library Services). Second, a project was launched in collaboration with the libraries at Columbia University and University of California, Berkeley, to develop a survey tool and launch a survey assessing the use of Internet Archives as a research tool. Finally, the Rutgers University and Internet Archive teams, in collaboration with colleagues in Journalism and Media Studies, launched a new project using the Media dataset to track the growth local news in 100 communities across the United States. The project, funded by the Democracy Fund will assess the long-term growth of local news ecosystems.
